t: Proverbs 14
Contrast the Upright and the Wicked
The*pn wise woman builds her house, But*ln the foolish tears it down with her own hands.
He*ln who walks in his uprightness fears the Lord,*s But*ln he who is devious in his ways despises Him.
In*ln the mouth of the foolish is a rod for his*i back, But*ln the lips of the wise will protect them.
Where*ln no oxen are, the manger is clean, But*ln much revenue comes*i by the strength of the ox.
A*ln trustworthy witness will not lie, But*ln a false witness utters lies.
A*ln scoffer seeks wisdom and finds*i none, But*ln knowledge is easy to one who has understanding.
Leave*ln the presence of a fool, Or*ln you will not discern words of knowledge.
The*ln wisdom of the sensible is to understand his way, But*ln the foolishness of fools is deceit.
Fools*ln mock at sin, But*ln among the upright there is good will.
The*ln heart knows its own bitterness, And*ln a stranger does not share its joy.
The*ln house of the wicked will be destroyed, But*ln the tent of the upright will flourish.
There*ln is a way which*i seems*i right to a man, But*ln its end is the way of death.
Even*ln in laughter the heart may be in pain, And*ln the end of joy may be grief.
The*ln backslider in heart will have his fill of his own ways, But*ln a good man will be*i satisfied*i with his.
The*ln naive believes everything, But*ln the sensible man considers his steps.
A*ln wise man is cautious and turns away from evil, But*ln a fool is arrogant and careless.
A*ln quick-tempered man acts foolishly, And*ln a man of evil devices is hated.
The*ln naive inherit foolishness, But*ln the sensible are crowned with knowledge.
The*ln evil will bow down before the good, And*ln the wicked at the gates of the righteous.
The*ln poor is hated even by his neighbor, But*ln those who love the rich are many.
He*ln who despises his neighbor sins, But*ln happy is he who is gracious to the poor.
Will*ln they not go astray who devise evil? But*ln kindness and truth will*i be*i to*i those who devise good.
In*ln all labor there is profit, But*ln mere talk leads*i only to poverty.
The*ln crown of the wise is their riches, But*iln the folly of fools is foolishness.
A*ln truthful witness saves lives, But*ln he who utters lies is treacherous.
In*ln the fear of the Lord*s there is strong confidence, And*ln his children will have refuge.
The*ln fear of the Lord*s is a fountain of life, That*ln one may avoid the snares of death.
In*ln a multitude of people is a king’s glory, But*ln in the dearth of people is a prince’s ruin.
He*ln who is slow to anger has great understanding, But*ln he who is quick-tempered exalts folly.
A*ln tranquil heart is life to the body, But*ln passion is rottenness to the bones.
He*ln who oppresses the poor taunts his Maker, But*ln he who is gracious to the needy honors Him.
The*ln wicked is thrust down by his wrongdoing, But*ln the righteous has a refuge when he dies.
Wisdom*ln rests in the heart of one who has understanding, But*ln in the hearts of fools it is made known.
Righteousness*ln exalts a nation, But*ln sin is a disgrace to any*i people.
The*ln king’s favor is toward a servant who acts wisely, But*ln his anger is toward him who acts shamefully.
